translation: Sutra on the Parable of King Aśoka Spoken by the Divine Honored One
Lost Translator's Names with Notes on the Eastern Jin Dynasty
Once upon a time, there was a great king.
His name was Aśoka.
He ruled over various countries, and none of them were subject to him.
The great king's intelligence and wisdom were immeasurable.
He taught and asked his ministers.
"Is there anyone under heaven who doesn't belong to me?
The ministers answered.
"The whole world belongs to the great king.
There's no one who isn't subdued.
One of the wise ministers replied.
"There's someone in the king's realm who doesn't belong to the king.
'There's a dragon king in the ocean who doesn't belong to the great king.'
At first, he didn't send faith, and he didn't contribute.
That's why they know they don't belong to the great king.
The king can try it out.
He'll ride a thousand vehicles and ten thousand horses.
They pound bells and beat drums.
Their banners guarded their pity as they went forward and backward to the sea's edge.
The dragon king remained calm and withdrew.
The king then called out to him, saying.
"You're inside my realm!
Why didn't you come out?
You also remained silent and didn't confront the king.
The king then asked the wise minister.
"How did you get the dragon king to come out?
The wise minister replied.
"It's possible to get him to emerge.
The dragon king's virtue is great.
That's why he wouldn't submit.
If the king doesn't believe my words, then...
I'll weigh two pounds of gold and cast two images.
One will be made into an image of the king.
One will be made into an image of the dragon king.
He then took it and weighed it.
The image of the dragon king is heavy, but the image of the great king is light.
The image of the great king is light.
This is how you know that the dragon king's fortune is great ...
The great king's fortune is small.
The king's mind was deeply understanding.
His joy was immeasurable.
He told the world to support the orphans and elderly.
He would go around in poverty and help the poor.
The prefectures in his area erected shrines to the goddess.
He also placed a relic of the goddess of honor to feed the people.

source_sentence: 三年之中復取龍像王像秤之。
translation: After three years, he then took the image of the dragon king and weighed it.
The image of the dragon then becomes lighter, and the image of the king becomes heavier.
The king's image then becomes heavy.
The wise minister said to the king.
"The dragon can be subdued now!

source_sentence: 便設鹵簿如前後復到海邊。
translation: He then set up a brine book as before and went back to the ocean's edge.
The dragon king took on the form of a young brāhmaṇa.
He knelt down in front of the king and asked about his upbringing and residence.

source_sentence: 貢獻海中所有珍寶奇好寶。
translation: He offered up all the treasures, wonders, and goodies in the ocean.
He declared himself his servant.
The people of the land were all delighted.
He wrote a separate sūtra.
It's to show the people of the world to come.
'The world's many powers are unsurpassed by virtue.
A person protects the sūtras and Dharma like a mother protects her child.
Isn't it inconceivable?
Once upon a time, when the Bhagavān was in the world.

source_sentence: 將諸弟子教化群生見地有一紙。
translation: He was teaching his disciples to teach the sentient beings, and he saw a piece of paper on the ground.
That disciple, Ānanda, quickly took it.
The Bhagavān told Ānanda to put it on the ground.
Ānanda then even put it on the ground.
His hand then smelled a great deal of incense.

source_sentence: 小復前行見飄風吹草在地。
translation: Again, he walked forward and saw grass blowing in the wind on the ground.
Ānanda then took it again.
The Bhagavān told Ānanda to put it on the ground.
"My hands will smell bad.
Ānanda didn't understand.

source_sentence: 須臾前到精舍當問此意。
translation: When he arrived at the monastery a moment later, he asked what that meant.
Ānanda said to the Bhagavān.
"What's the reason you grabbed a piece of paper and made your hand smell?
By grasping grass, it makes my hands smell.
The Bhagavān said to Ānanda.
"The paper originally came from the ground of fragrance.
The fragrance stuck to the paper.
That's why it makes your hands smell good.
Grass comes from a smelly place.
That's what makes your hands smell.
To be near a good person is like incense on paper.
To be near a bad person is like stinking grass.
That's why the sūtras say that being near a good person makes you wise ... and being near a fool makes you more confused.
Being close to a fool will increase your mental disturbances.
There are three things that harm me ...
There are three that benefit me.
This is called something that mustn't be borne in mind.

source_sentence: 昔天尊將諸弟子至江邊。
translation: Once, the Bhagavān sent his disciples to the river.
The Bhagavān told the disciples.
"Take a rock like a fistful of water.
Throw it in the water, and it will float or sink.'
The disciples replied.
"The stone is submerged in the water.
The Bhagavān said.
"There's no reason for it to be there.
"Furthermore, there's a stone that's three feet square.

source_sentence: 著於水上經便渡河石亦不濕云何得爾。
translation: How did it get that way when it was placed on top of the water and then crossed the river without getting wet?
The disciples didn't understand, but they all wondered about it.
The disciples knelt down and said to the Buddha.
"What is the reason for this?
The Bhagavān said.
"It's because there are good conditions.
"What are the conditions, boat?
The Bhagavān used it as a metaphor.
'It's the boat that's worthy of a good teacher.
They'll be spared all kinds of suffering.
When he meets a bad teacher, he'll cultivate bad habits and won't escape numerous calamities.
He then becomes accustomed to bad deeds and doesn't part with numerous calamities.
This is a warning to people of later generations.
They mustn't be careless.
Once, there was a poor, poor, orphaned man.
He had no means of making his own living.
He met a man in the marketplace who had an ax.
It was the brightest of many treasures.
He didn't know it.
He took it out for sale with a walking stick.
He wanted to use the ax for his modest livelihood and wanted to finish it.
He saw a great merchant from a foreign country who had grown up in control.
His name is Sapha.
When he saw the ax, he knew it.
He then asked the old man.
"Do you sell this ax?
The man said.

source_sentence: 我仰此斧斫杖生活不賣也。
translation: "I look up to this ax to chop down my staff for a living, but I won't sell it.
Sapha then said.
"Why don't you sell it for a hundred pounds of silk?
The man said, "Adjust yourself.
He shouldn't have mixed it up.'
Again, Sapha said.
"Why didn't you say 'yes'?
He gave the duke 200 hides.
The duke then became sad and unhappy.
Again, Sapha said.
'I think you'll get more for less.'
Why was he unhappy?
He gave him 500 horses.
The man then lamented and said.
"I don't hate having so little silk.

source_sentence: 我愚癡此斧長尺半斫地已盡。
translation: I'm a fool. This ax is a foot and a half long, and I've already chopped down the ground.
With the remaining five inches, I still have 500 hairs.
That's why I hate it.
Again, Sapha said.
"Don't let that be a grudge.
Now, I'll give you a thousand horses.
Even if you break the voucher, you can take it away.
'This is the ax, the finest of many treasures.'

source_sentence: 薩博不問多少以斧著上。
translation: Sapo didn't ask how much it was, but he put the axe on it.
Burning it on the fire, it becomes a precious treasure.
The Bhagavān uses this as a metaphor.

source_sentence: 以受人身六情完具聰智辯達。
translation: "Because he's received the human body, his six senses are perfectly equipped, and he's wise and insightful.

source_sentence: 當就明師以求度世之道。
translation: He should consult a wise teacher to find the way to save the world.
The supernormal powers are within his reach.
He's a mundane attachment who doesn't distinguish between true and false.
When the plow is turned loose, the world takes what's driven out.
They'll again be condemned in old age and death.
It's a metaphor like the old man using the precious axe to exhaust it.
Isn't that wrong?
Once upon a time, there was a bird on Loong that was called a parrot.
It took a turn and ended up on Mount Tai in the east.
All the birds, beasts, and birds of prey loved it.
It's because it came from far away.
They were like friends and relatives and were very fond of them.

source_sentence: 春月野火所燒便行入水。
translation: When it's burned by a wildfire in the spring, it travels into the water.

source_sentence: 飛在火上抖擻毛羽之水。
translation: It flies above the fire and shakes its feathers out of the water.
It saves a friend or relative from trouble.
They don't go back and forth in unison.

source_sentence: 悲鳴大吁鸚鵡之水豈能滅火。
translation: They cry out in pity, "How could the water of a parrot put out a fire?
With utmost sincerity, the gods sent rain down for him.
The fire was immediately extinguished.
The Sutra of the Goddess of Mercy uses this as a metaphor.

source_sentence: 賢者以道士遠到研精行道。
translation: "Good men, let's say that a Daoist travels far and studies and practices the Way.

source_sentence: 減割身口侵妻子分供養眾僧。
translation: He cuts off his body and mouth, invading his wife's share, and making offerings to the saṃgha.
Even though he wasn't moved by supernormal powers.
He still burns incense with utmost sincerity to seek their cessation.
He takes these salutations and raises them to obtain immeasurable merit.
It's like a heavenly shower that extinguishes all calamities.
Once, there was a great elder with measureless wealth.

source_sentence: 窖穀千斛後出之不見穀。
translation: He stored a thousand cubic meters of grain in a cellar and then left it without seeing any grain.

source_sentence: 見一小兒可年三歲亦不知語。
translation: He saw a little boy who was three years old and didn't know how to speak.
The elder didn't know what his name was either.
He held up his front door by the side of the road.
There are still pedestrians on the street who know it.
To the east of the house, a chariot came along.

source_sentence: 乘駕黃牛人著黃衣從人皆黃。
translation: It was riding in a yellow ox, and the people wearing yellow clothes were all yellow.
When he passed by, he saw the boy and said.
"How did the grain thief end up sitting here?
He's a child of the god of the five grains.
He said, 'That's an elder with a shovel.'
He said, "Come with the shovel and axe.
"I told you, 'Where's the pot of gold?'
That's the god of gold who first walked past it.
He went west along the road and got off on a southward circuit.
He walked 200 steps.
On the west side of the road there will be a rotten old tree.
Underneath it is a jar with ten cubic yards of gold.

source_sentence: 君往掘取可以還君穀直。
translation: You can dig it up and get it back to return your grain to the god.

source_sentence: 長者即隨小兒教得此治家足成大富。
translation: The elder then follows his youngest child's lead and teaches that he'll be able to make his family very wealthy with this.
The sūtras use this as a metaphor.

source_sentence: 供養眾僧廣設檀會交有所費。
translation: "Supplying to the saṃgha and setting up a large gathering of donations will cost you money.
It's a metaphor for losing grain.

source_sentence: 道士講經說義教人遠惡就善。
translation: A Daoist preaches the scriptures and teaches the meaning, teaching people to turn away from evil and toward goodness.
Subsequently, they attain immeasurable merit and then attain the Way.
It's a metaphor like getting a gold jar.
It's a sign to those who come after us.
"You mustn't fail to cultivate merit.
There's no limit to regret later.

source_sentence: 昔有國豐盛安樂無所渴乏。
translation: Once upon a time, there was a country that was abundant in well-being and happiness, and there was nothing to be desired.
It then told its minister.
"Send a servant who's worthy of being sent.

source_sentence: 至於他國市吾所無者市來。
translation: Suppose he went to another country and bought something we didn't have in the market.

source_sentence: 即遣一人往至他國益將珍寶遍市肆觀看無有餘物。
translation: He then sent a man to that country who would then go to the market and buy and sell treasures there, seeing that there was nothing left.
All of them are found in our country.

source_sentence: 最後見一賢者空坐肆上。
translation: Finally, he saw a good man sitting empty in the marketplace.
He asked him.
"I don't see anything you're selling.
Why are you sitting there empty?
He replied, 'I'm selling my wisdom here.'
He asked.
"What's the image of your wisdom that you're selling for how much?
He replied.
'My wisdom is worth 500 taels of gold.'

source_sentence: 前稱爾金吾當與汝說之耳。
translation: I'll tell you about this gold I've asked you for.
The farmer then thought to himself.
'There's no one in my country who sells wisdom to you.'
He then weighed 500 taels of gold and gave it to that person.
He then gave him the words of wisdom.
Twenty words," he said.
"Think long and hard about it.
'Don't be so hasty as to become angry.'
Even though he doesn't use it today.
There will be a time when it's useful.'

source_sentence: 於是受誦令利各自還家。
translation: He then recited them, making them beneficial as he returned home.

source_sentence: 臣買得智慧之言即便還國道徑其家。
translation: After I bought the words of wisdom, I returned to my country and followed the path to my home.

source_sentence: 夜入明月婦床前有兩履。
translation: At night, he entered the bright moonlight, and there were two shoes in front of his wife's bed.
Suspecting an outsider, she gave rise to bad thoughts.
The woman then suddenly became ill, and her mother went to stay overnight.

source_sentence: 視長者故說智慧之言未休。
translation: She looked at the elder and therefore spoke words of wisdom before she stopped.
Her mother was startled to learn that her son had come to stay with her.
The child then went out of the door and called her cheap.
His mother asked him.
"What did you do to get something?
Why did you call it cheap?'

source_sentence: 兒言我母以婦萬兩金猶不與人。
translation: The son said, "My mother wouldn't have given my mother 10,000 taels of gold for a woman.

source_sentence: 正顧五百兩金豈非賤耶。
translation: Wouldn't it be cheap to take care of 500 taels of gold?
The Sutra of the Goddess of Mercy uses this as a metaphor.
As the proverb goes, the help of a single word is better than the benefit of a thousand pieces of gold.
It's better than the benefit of a thousand pieces of gold.
This is also called.
Once, the goddess of merit was at the edge of the river.
He spoke the teachings of the sūtras at length.

source_sentence: 時天龍鬼神帝王人民飛鳥走獸皆來聽法。
translation: Then gods, dragons, ghosts, gods, people, birds, and animals all came to listen to the teaching.

source_sentence: 時有放牛老公柱杖而聽。
translation: Then, a herding cowherd man stuck his staff in the air and listened.
He didn't realize there was a toad underneath his staff.
The toad listened to the sūtra with beautiful intent.
He also didn't realize there was a staff on his back.
So long ago, the toad's life ended.
The spirit was then born in heaven.
He uses the divine eye to examine his original body.

source_sentence: 從何道中來乃見故身在蝦蟆中。
translation: Where did he come from? Then he saw his old body inside the toad.
He came to heaven with flowers scattered over his old body.
He told those who followed him.

source_sentence: 蝦蟆中聽經意美得生天上。
translation: 'The beauty of listening to the sūtras among toads is that their intent will be born in heaven.'
How much more so when a good man wholeheartedly listens to the sūtras?
Wouldn't that be lofty?
There once was a brother and a sister.
The younger brother pursued the luminous teacher and became an ascetic.
He then attained the path of a arhat.
Several times, he came to say to his brother.
"He can work hard to achieve virtue.
The older brother said.
"Now, I have hurriedly undertaken tasks that need to be done later.
The number is not one.
At the end of your life, I'll tell you.

source_sentence: 弟以道眼觀兄神生何道。
translation: With the eye of the Way, I'll examine what path your soul has taken.

source_sentence: 看天道人道其中不見其神。
translation: I see that I don't see your spirit in the paths of gods and humans.

source_sentence: 復觀地獄餓鬼道中復不見。
translation: I also observe that I don't see it again in the hell realm or the realm of hungry ghosts.
Instead, he was in the animal rebirth path.
I saw my brother's spirit build a huge ox.
The journeyman then drove the ox to rule over the living.
He couldn't get up from his seat in the mud on the road.
The traveler beat him with a stick.
He still swallowed uncontrollably and didn't get up.
Seeing my brother like that, my brother came to me and put himself in front of the ox.
He came out and put himself in front of the ox.
He said to him.
"How is hurried work today like it was before?
The cow then died of shame and embarrassment.
The Daoist then left.
The merchants and others then agreed, saying.
"Why did the Daoist come to curse and kill my cow?
They then chased after the Daoist.
They were about to return to him and ask him about his intentions.

source_sentence: 道人如事為說牛是我兄。
translation: The Daoist did as he asked, saying that the cow was my brother.
Not following my words caused this sin.
The Daoist then threw his bowl into the sky.
He flew after him.
The caravans knew he was a sage.
They then further rebuked themselves.
He burned incense for the cow and made it blessed.
That merit then allowed him to be born in heaven.
Once upon a time, there was a good man.
He lived 30 miles southeast of Śrāvastī.
His family dedicated themselves to making offerings to the Way.
The man liked to kill pigs and sell meat.
The Daoist gradually came to know about it.
He didn't have time to admonish him.
The old man then took his life and died.
He was exposed to the form of a ghost in the still waters.
He had his own iron wheel with a blade like frost and snow.
It stabs him with the current.
The pain was unspeakable.

source_sentence: 後日道人渡恒水在正與鬼神相值。
translation: The day after that, the Way man crossed the Gaṅgā River and met the demon in the water.
The demon then emerged with half its body on the water.
It grabbed the boat and looked after it, saying.
'Catch the Wayfarer in the water!'
If you don't, it will kill everyone on board.
Then, there was a good man who asked the demon.
"Why did you ask this man of the Way?
The demon spirit said.
"When I was here in the world, I supported the Way man.
The Way man's people knew that I killed pigs and sold meat.
He didn't admonish me.
That's why I killed the religious practitioner.
The good man then said.
'Your sitting there killing pigs has caused this sin.
Now, you want to kill a practitioner of the Way.
Wouldn't that be a greater offense?

source_sentence: 鬼神思惟實如賢者之言。
translation: The demon spirit thought, "It's really like what that good man said.
They then released him and let him go.

source_sentence: 道人得去還語其家子孫。
translation: When he got away, the Daoist returned to his family and told their descendants.
"They'll make it a point to pursue their merits.
The spirits then were spared suffering.
He told the world that followed him.

source_sentence: 道人受供養不可不教誡。
translation: "A practitioner of the Way who accepts offerings mustn't fail to instruct others.
Once, a man was walking on the path.
He saw a dead man on the path.
The demon whipped him with a stick.
The practitioner asked.
"Why is this person being whipped when he's already dead?
The demon spirit said.
"It's my old body.
When I was alive, I wasn't dutiful to my parents.
He was unfaithful to his ruler.
He didn't respect the three honored ones.
I didn't follow the teachings of my master.
It caused me to fall into misdeeds and suffer unspeakable pain.
I was whipped because of my former body.
Walking a little further, he then saw a dead man.

source_sentence: 天神來下散華於死人屍上。
translation: The gods came down and scattered flowers on the dead man's corpse.
He put his hand on his head and rubbed it against it.
The pedestrian asked, "Look, you look like a god!
"Look, you look like a god.
Why is he rubbing his hand over the dead body?
He replied.

source_sentence: 是我故身生時之日孝順父母。
translation: 'It's because I was filial to my parents the day my body was born.
I was loyal and faithful to my ruler.
I honored the three honored ones.
I accepted my master's teaching.
It allowed my spirit to be born in heaven.
These were all the kindnesses of my late body.
This is how I've rewarded them.
One day, a practitioner sees these two transformations.

source_sentence: 便還家奉持五戒修行十善。
translation: He then returns home, observes the five precepts, and cultivates the ten good qualities.
He should honor his parents, be faithful, and serve his ruler.
He shows and tells those who come after him.
"Sins and merits pursue people for a long time without abandoning them.
They mustn't be careless.
There once was a man of the Way.
He was studying the path in the mountains.
They sent a novice out to guard his house.

source_sentence: 日日責一斗米兼課一偈。
translation: Every day, he was instructed to give a bucket of rice and a verse.
There was a good man sitting in a restaurant in the city.
He saw the novice walking alongside him, saying.
He asked the novice, "Why is he walking around searching for something?

source_sentence: 周行走索何以並語而行。
translation: "Why is he walking around searching for something to do while speaking at the same time?
Śākyamuni replied.
"My teacher is training on the path in the mountains.

source_sentence: 日責我米一斗兼課一偈。
translation: Every day, he gives me a bucket of rice and a verse to recite.
That's why I'm walking around reciting one verse at a time.
Again, the Bhagavān asked.
"How many verses can I know every day if I don't give out rice?
He said he could learn ten verses.
The good man then said.
"Don't further divide it.
'I'll give rice on behalf of the novice.'

source_sentence: 沙彌歡喜即得靜坐學問。
translation: The śrāmaṇer rejoiced and was able to sit quietly and study.

source_sentence: 賢者為沙彌輸米九斛米。
translation: The good man then gave the śrāmaṇer nine measures of rice.

source_sentence: 然後試沙彌經皆自通利。
translation: Then he tested the śrāmaṇeras' sūtras, and they all became proficient.

source_sentence: 賢者後生世間為天尊作弟子。
translation: Good man was later born in the world and became a disciple of the Bhagavān.
His name was Ānanda.
The goddess has 12 scriptures.

source_sentence: 聰明之福報不可謂問一知十。
translation: The merit of intelligence can't be described as knowing ten by asking one question.
He told people in the future.
"Merits carry with them like shadows and follow their forms.
Each person will obtain their own merit based on what they've planted.
It's not impossible to do so.

source_sentence: 昔有屠兒有千頭牛養令肥好。
translation: Once, a butcher had a thousand head of cattle that he kept fat and healthy.
Every day, he would kill one cow and sell it for meat.
He then killed 500 of them.
The remaining 500 head were left behind.

source_sentence: 方共跳騰諠戲共相觝觸。
translation: They all jumped around, played, and fought each other.
The Bhagavān then entered his country.
He saw how the oxen were behaving and abandoned them.
He told his disciples.
"This cow is foolish.
When its companions' desires are exhausted, they'll play together.
So it is with humans.
One day passes, and human life decreases.

source_sentence: 人命轉減不可不思惟勤求度世之道。
translation: When human life decreases, you mustn't stop thinking about it and diligently seek the way to save the world.
The Bhagavān spoke the parable of King Aśoka.
